item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Oh, and apparently MarsEdit updates posts by doing this:

  1. Update post (setting status to draft)
  2. Update categories for post.
  3. Set post status to "published"

It does this to prevent posts from acting weirdly as they're being updated, but something is triggering an error message as part of the first step (even though the post is successfully edited in WordPress), and so MarsEdit gives up on the later steps, and the post never gets switched back to "Published"

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Just verified this is still present in 1.5 (final).

item.title: Ticket #887 (Smilies with apostrophes are Smarty-ified before being parsed (like :'( )) updated
item.dc:creator: sethkinast

item.title: Ticket #887 (Smilies with apostrophes are Smarty-ified before being parsed (like :'( )) created
item.dc:creator: sethkinast
item.description:
As seen here: ​http://sethkinast.com/blog/archive/2005/02/14/happy-singles-awareness-day/#comment-2177

The function that turns straight apostrophes into forward and back apostrophes fires before the smiley parser. Smilies should be parsed first so things like the crying face :'( work.

item.title: Ticket #886 (admin css missing when changing wp directory) updated
item.dc:creator: trevorturk

item.title: Ticket #886 (admin css missing when changing wp directory) created
item.dc:creator: trevorturk
item.description:
if you change your wp installation directory, the admin css goes missing. here are the instructions:

​http://wordpress.org/docs/installation/different-address/

You can solve the problem by changing:

<?php echo get_settings('siteurl') ?>

to

<?php bloginfo('wpurl') ?>

in admin-header.php on line 9.

perhaps the documentation could be updated, and/or the reference to the css file could be changed by the developers?

item.title: Ticket #881 (Lengthen password field for protected posts) updated
item.dc:creator: ScytheBlade1
item.description:
Actually, a possible idea as to implimentation:

1) On the side of the password area, add a checkbox labeled "Encrypt Password". Make it a link to documentation explaining: -That by checking this box, you have no way of obtaining your password again, less resetting it -This also allows you to enter passwords much greater than 20 in length When this box is checked, and you're editing the post, the password box should display "[Encrypted]". When the form is submitted, if that field has changed at all from that string, simply update the password. 2) Just the same, make it at least 50 for plaintext. I tend to use phrases instead of passwords, that go along with the post title.

I made the change locally in my database (to raise the limit to 50), it really is a "why not" thing. The encryption option is only an added bonus that's easily implimented alongside it.

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) closed
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #881 (Lengthen password field for protected posts) updated
item.dc:creator: ScytheBlade1

item.title: Ticket #881 (Lengthen password field for protected posts) created
item.dc:creator: ScytheBlade1
item.description:
You know, if you lengthen the database column size to 32 and then just md5() it, users essentially would have unlimited password length for a post. However, since I take it that the ability to actually see the password that you input is enjoyed in wordpress, increasing the max length to 50 or so would be greatly appreciated.

It's just that 20 is so short...

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) updated

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) updated

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) created
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description:
Some feed generators (in this case GeekLog) place the CDATA tag in the title. import-rss.php does not remove it.

changed line 58 to: $title = str_replace( array('<![CDATA,?]>'), , addslashes( trim($title[1]) ) );

item.title: Ticket #878 (rss2 import switches values for post_date and post_date_gmt) updated
item.dc:creator: pgarrett

item.title: Ticket #878 (rss2 import switches values for post_date and post_date_gmt) created
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description:
When importing an rss2 feed I discovered all posts dats were set to GMT time and the offset seemed to be ignored. Found that the values were simply being switched. Made the following changed to lined 148-149 in import-rss.php

148: switch variables DATE_ADD('$post_date', INTERVAL '$add_hours:$add_minutes' HOUR_MINUTE) and '$post_date'

149: replace $post_date with DATE_ADD('$post_date', INTERVAL '$add_hours:$add_minutes' HOUR_MINUTE)

item.title: Ticket #867 (single_month_title() broken for single-digit months) updated
item.dc:creator: dimock
item.description:
Status, Resolution changed

Change was applied to wrong line. Correct version (see lines with '*'):

function single_month_title($prefix = , $display = true ) {

global $m, $monthnum, $month, $year; if(!empty($monthnum) && !empty($year)) {

$my_year = $year;

* $my_month = $month[str_pad($monthnum, 2, '0', STR_PAD_LEFT)];

} elseif(!empty($m)) {

$my_year = substr($m, 0, 4);

* $my_month = $month[substr($m, 4, 2)];

}

if (!empty($my_month) && $display) {

echo $prefix . $my_month . $prefix . $my_year;

} else {

return $monthnum;

}

}

item.title: Changeset [2337]: Tidy spacing a little

item.title: Ticket #773 (mod_rewrite rules don't work with https) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
The protocol section (http:) isn't used, but the incorrect RewriteBase rule that is created on https: sites, causes problems.

Under http: we get a RewriteBase that looks like:

RewriteBase /wordpress/

with RewriteRules like:

RewriteRule (page-title)/trackback/?$ /wordpress/index.php?pagename=$1&tb=1 [QSA,L]

But under https: we get:

RewriteBase www.example.ac.uk/wordpress/

The subsequent RewriteRule entries then look like:

RewriteRule (page-title)/trackback/?$ www.example.ac.uk/wordpress/index.php?pagename=$1&tb=1 [QSA,L]

Which results in an http: url rather than https:

I've taken another look at the code, with a fresher eye this time, and can see that the lines:

$site_root = str_replace('​http://', , trim(get_settings('siteurl')));

and

$home_root = str_replace('​http://', , trim(get_settings('home')));

both in function mod_rewrite_rules() in wp-includes/classes.php are the source of this problem. Neither correctly handles an 'https:' in the siteurl or home settings.

Replacing them with:

$site_root = ereg_replace('http(s){0,1}:', , trim(get_settings('siteurl')));

and

$home_root = ereg_replace('http(s){0,1}:', , trim(get_settings('home')));

solves the problem.

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan

item.title: Ticket #876 (Identify mod_rewrite at install, and if not there, use ...) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
apache_get_modules() is available only in php 4.3.2 or higher. We must work with 4.1. Also, some hosts don't enable AcceptPathInfo, meaning that the index.php method won't work either. So, we'll probably have to leave permalinks off by default for now.

edited on: 02-14-05 23:05

item.title: Ticket #847 (/archives/%post_id% permalinks break for post ids over 999.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan

item.title: Ticket #876 (Identify mod_rewrite at install, and if not there, use ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Joen

item.title: Ticket #876 (Identify mod_rewrite at install, and if not there, use ...) created
item.dc:creator: Joen
item.description:
Currently, Wordpress has a fairly basic link structure when mod_rewrite is not installed / used.

MediaWiki, on the other hand, has a link structure that is almost similar with and without mod_rewrite. The only difference being "index.php/".

A Wordpress example would be: With rewrite rules: website.com/2005/02/01/postname Without rewrite rules: website.com/index.php/2005/02/01/postname

Ideally, this would be detected when Wordpress is first setup. If mod_rewrite is found, then the nice permalinks are written to the .htaccess. Otherwise, option 2 is used.

Possible? Worthwhile?

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description:
Agreed; this isn't a problem with the plugins, but rather the sequence in which WordPress prepares post excerpts.

Currently, I'm not even sure if WordPress applies the plugin filters to the excerpts. Here's what the preparation sequence seems to be currently:

  • Strip HTML tags from post
  • Truncate post and append ellipsis

Here's what it *should* be:

  • Apply any post filter plugins (such as Markdown or Textile)
  • Strip HTML tags from post
  • Truncate post and append ellipsis

Without that first step, the underlying syntax of the post will be exposed.

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated
item.dc:creator: Michel Fortin
item.description:
It's not that simple. Markdown does not filter the excerpt currently because it can't do so reliably. The problem is that tags are filtered by WordPress *before* going to Markdown, removing any part of the syntax that looks like a tag. For example, if I write this:

An autolink: <​http://somewhere.com>

A code span: <code>.

The auto link will be removed before Markdown has a chance to see it, and the same applies to the tag inside the code span. (The code tag here would be entity-encoded by Markdown, so it's not really a tag in the final output.)

WordPress should strip tags *after* the excerpt has been filtered. The current tag filter is hard-coded, so it cannot be removed or be put after Markdown.

edited on: 02-14-05 12:04

item.title: Ticket #873 ((patch included) Add user-agent field to trackbacks) updated
item.dc:creator: error

item.title: Ticket #873 ((patch included) Add user-agent field to trackbacks) created
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: This patch (made against 1.5 but should apply to 1.2 with some fuzz/offset) adds a User-Agent: field to outgoing trackbacks. Some users use User-Agent field to determine if the client making the connection is valid, and will treat blank user agents more harshly. This lets people identify incoming trackbacks as WordPress software.

item.title: Changeset [2321]: html_type to allow for true XHTML.

item.title: Ticket #871 ((patch included) XHTML error empty ul in wp_list_pages) updated
item.dc:creator: error

item.title: Ticket #871 ((patch included) XHTML error empty ul in wp_list_pages) created
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: In wp_list_pages() when pages have children, but the children are not displayed, an XHTML validation error occurs because of an empty <ul></ul> being generated when the children are not displayed. The attached patch fixes the issue.

item.title: Ticket #870 (php gzip encoding does not occur on output buffering) updated
item.dc:creator: error

item.title: Ticket #870 (php gzip encoding does not occur on output buffering) created
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: Since 1.5-gamma 2005-02-12 or so, WordPress no longer appears to be gzip encoding pages, even when browsers state they are capable of accepting gzip encoding. All pages go out uncompressed.
